page.title: 13LOCAL HISTORY, CHELWOOD GATE
page.content:
Recent pipeline excavations in the forest revealed small flints dated neolithic and mesolithic periods, then an archaeological dig there uncovered a possible pre-Roman defense earthwork on the late Iron Age track. Bunce (Birch) Grove is mentioned in Domes- day. In 1268 Ashdown Forest was en- closed as a Royal Hunting Forest re- sulting in local place names of "hatch" and "gate". The oldest habi- tation dates from the 17th century.
Stumblewood and Chelwood Commons, bordering the forest, in the Manor of Broadhurst, were enclosed in 1864; the land divided into plots on Chel- wood Common giving its present character. Stumblets in the area show connections with the nearby iron workings.
